questions.question: A project manager tracks equipment, materials, and team members. Which does the Resources performance domain cover?
options: Only team members - equipment is procurement
Only equipment and materials - people are in a different domain
All of them - human resources AND physical/virtual resources
Only external resources obtained through contracts
questions.explanation: The Resources performance domain covers BOTH human resources (project team) AND physical/virtual resources (equipment, materials, facilities, software, licenses). Many PMs focus only on people, but physical resource constraints can block projects just as badly.

questions.question: A matrix organization PM needs a specific engineer but that person's functional manager says 'no.' What does this illustrate?
options: The PM has full authority over all resources
The PM may need to negotiate with resource managers who control team assignments
The engineer should be fired
Matrix organizations don't work
questions.explanation: In matrix organizations, PMs don't 'own' resources - functional/resource managers do. PMs must negotiate, influence, and sometimes escalate to acquire needed team members. Understanding this organizational dynamic is critical for acquiring and retaining the right resources.

questions.question: A new team is experiencing conflict and disagreements as members push back on approaches and compete for influence. According to Tuckman, what stage is this?
options: Forming - the team is just getting started
Storming - conflict is normal as personalities clash and roles are established
Norming - the team is settling down
Adjourning - the team is disbanding
questions.explanation: Storming is when conflict emerges as team members' personalities clash and they compete for position. This is NORMAL and necessary. Trying to skip storming suppresses healthy conflict. Understanding Tuckman helps PMs support teams through transitions rather than being alarmed by conflict.

questions.question: For a task, Sarah does the work, Mike approves it, Tom provides input, and Lisa needs to know when it's done. Using RACI, what are their roles?
options: Sarah=Accountable, Mike=Responsible, Tom=Informed, Lisa=Consulted
Sarah=Responsible, Mike=Accountable, Tom=Consulted, Lisa=Informed
Sarah=Consulted, Mike=Informed, Tom=Responsible, Lisa=Accountable
They all share responsibility equally
questions.explanation: RACI: Responsible (does work) = Sarah, Accountable (approves/owns outcome) = Mike, Consulted (provides input) = Tom, Informed (kept updated) = Lisa. Key rule: only ONE person is Accountable per task, ensuring clear ownership.

questions.question: A team member says 'I don't feel empowered to make decisions - I have to escalate everything.' Why is this a problem?
options: It's not a problem - all decisions should be escalated
Lack of empowerment slows decisions, reduces engagement, and prevents people from contributing their best work
The team member should just follow orders
Only senior people should make decisions
questions.explanation: Empowered people make better decisions closer to the work, feel ownership, and are more motivated. Micromanagement kills engagement and slows everything. Teams with appropriate empowerment (clear boundaries, not unlimited authority) outperform those requiring escalation for every decision.

questions.question: A virtual team struggles with collaboration and trust. What practices might help?
options: Convert everyone to in-person work
Use collaboration technology, schedule regular video meetings, consider at least one face-to-face kickoff, and create explicit team agreements
Virtual teams cannot work effectively
Reduce communication to minimize conflict
questions.explanation: Virtual teams need deliberate effort - collaboration sites, video conferencing, messaging tools, explicit working agreements, and ideally at least one in-person meeting to build relationships. Technology enables but doesn't guarantee success; intentional practices make the difference.

questions.question: Why does PMBOK have a separate 'Lead the Team' process rather than just 'Manage the Team'?
options: They're the same thing
Leadership (influencing, motivating, enabling) differs from management (planning, measuring) - both are needed
Leadership is optional
Management is more important than leadership
questions.explanation: Management focuses on processes, plans, and measurement. Leadership focuses on people - influencing, motivating, listening, enabling. You can manage perfectly and still fail if people aren't inspired. High-performing teams need both management AND leadership.

questions.question: A project needs 5 senior developers but only 3 are available. The PM is offered 5 junior developers instead. What should the PM do?
options: Accept any resources - something is better than nothing
Document the impact (training needs, schedule risk, quality concerns) and make an informed decision about whether alternatives are acceptable
Reject the project entirely
Demand the senior developers
questions.explanation: Resource substitution has consequences - skill mismatches affect quality, schedule, and risk. The PM should document impacts (training time, lower initial productivity, potential quality issues) and make an informed decision. Sometimes alternatives are acceptable; sometimes they're not.

questions.question: What are characteristics associated with high-performing project teams?
options: Strict hierarchy, individual accountability, competition between members
Open communication, shared understanding, trust, collaboration, adaptability, empowerment
High turnover and frequent reorganization
Avoiding all conflict
questions.explanation: High-performing teams exhibit: open communication, shared understanding of goals, shared ownership, mutual trust, collaboration (not silos), adaptability, resilience, and empowerment. These aren't accidental - they're cultivated through deliberate leadership practices.

questions.question: Equipment ordered 6 weeks ago still hasn't arrived, potentially delaying the project. Which process should have caught this earlier?
options: Acquire Resources - ordering is done once
Monitor and Control Resourcing - tracking resource availability and taking corrective action
Lead the Team - this is a people issue
Estimate Resources - the estimate was wrong
questions.explanation: Monitor and Control Resourcing ensures resources are available as planned, monitors planned vs. actual, and takes corrective action for shortages. Proactive monitoring would have detected the delivery issue earlier, allowing time for alternatives or escalation.

questions.question: A PM can read the room, manage their own stress, and understand why a team member is frustrated even when unstated. What skill is this?
options: Technical expertise
Emotional Intelligence - recognizing and managing emotions in self and others
Political awareness
Financial acumen
questions.explanation: Emotional Intelligence (EI) includes self-awareness, self-regulation, empathy, and social skills. Projects are done by people with emotions. A PM who can't read emotional cues, manage stress, or empathize will damage morale and relationships.

questions.question: Two team members have a technical disagreement. The PM facilitates a discussion where they find a solution that incorporates ideas from both. What conflict resolution style is this?
options: Competing - one person wins
Collaborating - finding a win-win solution together
Avoiding - postponing the conflict
Accommodating - one gives in
questions.explanation: Collaborating (problem-solving) seeks a win-win where all parties contribute to a mutually satisfying solution. It takes more time than other styles but produces better outcomes and maintains relationships. PMI generally favors this style for important conflicts.

questions.question: A team works in the same physical location - everyone can see and talk to each other easily. What is this called and why might it help?
options: Remote work
Colocation - improves communication, builds relationships, enables quick problem-solving
Matrix organization
Outsourcing
questions.explanation: Colocation places team members together physically. Benefits include spontaneous conversations, faster problem-solving, stronger relationships, and team identity. Even temporary colocation (kickoff week) can accelerate team formation.

questions.question: Team ground rules are established at project start. Why bother with this when experienced professionals 'should know how to behave'?
options: Ground rules are only for junior teams
Explicit ground rules prevent misunderstandings - people's assumptions about 'normal' behavior differ
Ground rules slow down the team
Professional standards make ground rules unnecessary
questions.explanation: Without explicit ground rules, people assume their own rules apply. What's 'normal' for one person might be offensive to another. Ground rules agreed together create shared expectations - meeting etiquette, communication norms, decision process - and a foundation for accountability.

questions.question: The proposal promised a specific expert, but that person left the company. What resource management concept is relevant?
options: Team development
Pre-assignment - the expert was designated before project start, creating a constraint
Resource leveling
Training
questions.explanation: Pre-assignment occurs when specific resources are designated before the project starts, often through contracts or proposals. Pre-assigned resources become constraints - the PM must plan around their availability. When pre-assigned resources are unavailable, it creates significant risk.

questions.question: A Resource Histogram shows one person scheduled for 160% capacity next month. What does this reveal?
options: They will work overtime
Over-allocation - the person is scheduled for more work than possible, requiring resolution
Normal scheduling
High productivity
questions.explanation: Histograms visualize resource allocation over time. 160% capacity = over-allocation. This isn't sustainable and must be resolved through resource leveling, acquiring additional resources, or adjusting the schedule. The histogram makes the problem visible.

questions.question: A PM publicly recognizes a team member's contribution at a meeting. The team member seems embarrassed rather than pleased. What went wrong?
options: Recognition is always appreciated
Recognition should be tailored to what individuals value - some prefer private acknowledgment
The PM should never give recognition
Only monetary rewards matter
questions.explanation: Effective recognition is aligned with what individuals value. Some want public praise; others find it embarrassing and prefer private acknowledgment or different forms of recognition. Know your team members and tailor recognition appropriately.

questions.question: The PM sends the team to training on a new technology. Some view this as an expense; the PM views it as an investment. Why?
options: Training is always an expense
Training pays back in improved productivity, fewer errors, and higher quality - it's an investment in capability
The PM is wrong
Training only benefits the individual
questions.explanation: Training costs upfront but pays back through improved productivity, fewer mistakes, and higher quality. Teams with skill gaps underperform. Viewing training as investment rather than expense leads to building organizational capability rather than cutting corners.

questions.question: The PM needs a resource from another department but has no authority to assign them. What skill is most important?
options: Technical expertise
Negotiation - PMs often must influence without authority to acquire resources
Financial analysis
Risk management
questions.explanation: PMs rarely have direct authority over resources, especially in matrix organizations. Negotiation skills - understanding interests, finding win-win solutions, building relationships - are essential for acquiring the right resources without command authority.

questions.question: A Resource Breakdown Structure (RBS) categorizes all project resources by type. How is this similar to a WBS?
options: They are unrelated
Both are hierarchical decompositions - WBS for work, RBS for resources - ensuring completeness
RBS is a subset of WBS
WBS is a subset of RBS
questions.explanation: Like the WBS decomposes work hierarchically, the RBS decomposes resources by category and type (labor, equipment, materials). It helps ensure all resource needs are identified and supports resource leveling, cost categorization, and identifying shortages by type.
